Award.AwardTitle: TRANSFORM: Teaching Research Advancement Network to Secure Female Faculty For Organizational Retention and Management

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Gannon University is a private, Roman Catholic, primarily undergraduate institution. The institution, through an ADVANCE PAID award proposes to implement strategies toward developing a teaching-research-advancement network to promote the retention and advancement of women faculty in the STEM disciplines. This approach is recognized by the institution as being essential since there exists a current shift in focus from teaching centeredness to research and scholarly productivity. It is envisaged that the proposed ADVANCE interventions will serve to prevent the marginalization of women faculty from the research enterprise at a critical time in the institution?s history. There are four objectives associated with this goal that include: recruiting and retaining women faculty, advancing women faculty through the professorial ranks, preparing women faculty for leadership positions and providing training for institutional leaders about gender equity issues. To achieve these objectives, the Gannon ADVANCE PAID project will utilize dual career services, initiate research awards and institutionalize leadership development programs.

Intellectual Merit
The proposed project at Gannon University adapts several successful best practices from other ADVANCE institutions in a meaningful way. As such, the expected outcomes of this project are poised to serve as a model for other institutions of similar type and with similar goals of research accomplishment. Specifically, this project presents strategies for leadership, dual career hiring and research initiation for women faculty at a moderately sized institution.

Broader Impact
The Gannon University ADVANCE PAID project will use traditional means of disseminating project outcomes and successes as well as innovative means, which include, but are not limited to conference manuscripts and newsletter articles to national organizations with interests in promoting gender equity in the STEM disciplines, and a postcard campaign summarizing grant activities and outcomes. Thus, this project will not only serve to ensure the broad participation of women faculty in the STEM disciplines, but also address the needs of a cadre of institutions that remain underrepresented in the ADVANCE award portfolio.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In 2011, Gannon University was awarded a five-year NSF ADVANCE Partnerships for Adaptation, Implementation, and Dissemination grant: Award # 1107015; Title: Teaching-Research-Advancement Network to Secure Female Faculty for Organizational Retention and Management (TRANSFORM); Amount: $385,919; 09/01/2011-08/31/2017. The goal of TRANSFORM was to increase the recruitment, retention, advancement, and leadership development for the STEM female faculty at Gannon. Three strategies were deployed to achieve this goal: 1) dual career services, 2) Research Initiation Award, and 3) leadership development opportunities for faculty.

Impact of NSF ADVANCE Award: TRANSFORM has successfully implemented all three of its strategies. Many institutional changes have occurred since the beginning of the award:

Progress in female representation

  • Increase in the number of female STEM full professors: 0% (0/64) in 2009-2010 versus 5.1% (4/79) in 2015-16 and 6.2% (5/81) in 2016-17.
  • Increase in awareness of leadership aspirations: In 2004-2005, 20% of the STEM chairs/program directors were female; in 2014-2015, 33% were female.

Policies and Procedures

  • Formalization of the release time process across the university: In 2009-2010, no formal, university-wide process existed although 26 faculty in the School of Engineering and Computer Science regularly received three credits per semester. In 2014, a formal process was established for all faculty. By 2015-16, 40 requests were received, 39 awards granted, and 199 release credits realized.
  • Prioritization of faculty by rank to receive internal Faculty Research and Development Grants.

Resources

  • Dual career support for all current and prospective employees through membership in the regional Higher Education Recruitment Consortium (HERC).
  • Increased funding for internal Faculty Research and Development Grants
  • Leadership programming was established for faculty.

All in all, positive impacts have been made in the institution and the culture. The ADVANCE funds provided the impetus for Gannon University to examine its processes, to drive its culture forward, and to realize positive changes.

TRANSFORM Intellectual Merit: The activities of each strategy have been incorporated into the university culture and are being sustained by the university. Gannon University supports the Dual Career Strategy through membership in a regional HERC, an online community that allows faculty and their partners to search for regional professional positions and Gannon University to advertise jobs to a wide audience of academic professionals. The Research Initiation Awards Strategy has transitioned into a formal process for scholarly release time for faculty in all three colleges at the university. Finally, leadership training for faculty, and for chairs and program directors will be continued through the Center for Excellence in Teaching and Learning under the oversight of the vice president for academic administration. A pilot of the Leadership Institute took placed in the spring of 2017 focusing on new managers in academic and non-academic departments. The development of this program is ongoing but plans to offer workshops with topics similar to the curriculum developed by TRANSFORM.

TRANSFORM Broader Impact: TRANSFORM’s impact has been realized, as female faculty have been retained, advanced in rank, and tenured at Gannon University. Moreover, these women have assumed leadership roles at the university, in their professions, and within the communities in which they live. The work-life balance of all faculty at Gannon University has been improved through grant activities now sustained by the university, such as increased scholarly release time, increased funds for scholarship and development, and extensive leadership training. Recruitment of faculty has been enhanced through membership in a regional HERC. Further, TRANSFORM has enhanced the future presence of female faculty by improving the conditions for career satisfaction and growth. This effort have been published in the 2016 American Society for Engineering Education Conference. Results have been disseminated through poster presentations at the Association of American Colleges and Universities 2015 Transforming STEM Education Conference, the 2013-14 NSF ADVANCE and the 2015-17 NSF ADVANCE/GSE Program Workshops.
